clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Motor Imagery and Action Observation on Static and Dynamic Balance: A Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The main objective of this research is to see the effect of two mental practice techniques on static and dynamic balance.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change in immediately at the end of the intervention.
primary_outcome.description: The device is a robotic device that evaluates motor function and consists of wirelessly sensed electromechanical platforms. This allows the evaluation of static and dynamic balance.

secondary_outcome.measure: Visual and Kinesthetic Motor Imagery Ability
secondary_outcome.description: The degree of physical activity was objectified through the The International Physical Activity Questionnaire (IPAQ) questionnaire, which allows the subjects to be divided into three groups according to their level of activity, which can be high, moderate, and low or inactive. The IPAQ consists of 7 questions about the frequency, duration and intensity of activity (moderate and intense) performed in the last seven days, as well as walking and sitting time on a workday. The IPAQ scoring protocol assigns the following MET values to walking, moderate, and vigorous intensity activity: 3.3 METs, 4.0 METs, and 8.0 METs, respectively.

intervention.description: Motor imagery group will have to imagine motor gestures of static and dynamic balance
Action observation group will have to observe static and dynamic equilibrium motor gestures
This group will watch a video of nature without a human component.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age between 18 and 60
- Healthy and with no pain subjects
Exclusion Criteria:
- Any cognitive impairment that hindered viewing of audiovisual material.
- Difficulty understanding or communicating.
- Presence of systemic pathology, Central Nervous System or rheumatic disease.
- Inadequate understanding of the Spanish language to follow instructions for measuring and treatment.
- Collaboration of pregnant women.
- Underage subjects
- Subjects with pain at the time of the study.
